headline: The Jolt: David Perdue to Brian Kemp: I made you governor
author: Tia Mitchell
sentences:
Since it's Friday, we always like to send you into the weekend with the columns from the week you might have missed, including:
Wednesday's Political Insider column on the latest AJC poll: OPINION: Rigged and Stolen' isn't winning for Donald Trump's GOP slate so far;?
Jamie DuPree's Washington Insider column Thursday, Opinion: Trump's influence to be tested in coming weeks;? and
A sneak peek of Sunday's Political Insider column, OPINION: The big-money industry to defeat Marjorie Taylor Greene.?

Brian Kemp and his Democratic challenger Stacey Abrams, at least slightly, by ruling that the governor has to wait to use his newly created leadership committee.? More from the AJC's James Salzer:
Judge Mark Cohen ruled that Kemp's leadership committee  Georgians First  can't raise any more money unless he becomes the party's nominee.

Here is a roundup of the flurry of letters sent in Washington this week:
U.S. Rep. Carolyn Bourdeaux and U.S. Sen. Raphael Warnock were the lead authors on a letter encouraging congressional leaders to include Medicaid expansion if they make any further attempts to pass a social spending bill.

U.S. Reps. Rick Allen, R-Augusta, and Barry Loudermilk, R-Cassville, wrote a letter to Georgia Schools Superintendent Richard Woods saying they are concerned about lessons on voting rights created by the New Georgia Project and used by Atlanta high schools.

Lawmakers in Washington often use letters to other public officials both to advocate for certain changes at the local, state or federal level and also to get their message out on various policy positions.

State Rep. Houston Gaines, a Republican from Athens, has requested a legislative investigation into a newly formed board in Athens-Clarke County meant to provide civilian oversight of the police there.
The Athens Banner-Herald reports Gaines' letter stems from text messages sent by a Democratic member of the city-county commission about the make-up of the board, which is meant to be nonpartisan.
